title: 105_hr1381
content: REVOLVING FUND. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury, administered by the Foundation. It consists of appropriated amounts and funds from section 11. The Foundation will use the Revolving Fund for operating the Institute, including salaries, mediation services, and other necessary expenses. The Revolving Fund is separate from the Trust Fund and is not subject to certain program priorities. The Revolving Fund established for the United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution is to be invested by the Secretary of the Treasury in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The investments can be made on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price, and any acquired obligations can be sold at market price. The interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption of the obligations are credited to the fund. Proceeds from the sale or redemption of obligations in the Revolving Fund are credited to and become part of the fund. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to allow the use of the Institute by a federal agency. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to authorize federal agencies to utilize the Foundation and the Institute for assessment, mediation, or related services in environmental, public lands, or natural resources disputes. Federal agencies can contract and pay for Institute services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Agencies must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute for such services. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 allows federal agencies to use the Foundation or Institute for environmental dispute resolution. Notifications must include details of the issues, prior efforts, and other relevant information. Concurrence from the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality is required for disputes involving multiple federal agencies before utilizing the Foundation or Institute. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 allows federal agencies to use the Foundation or Institute for environmental dispute resolution, with notifications required before utilizing the services described in subsection (a). SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for the Trust Fund and Revolving Fund, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 1998 through 2002. SEC. 9. Conforming amendments. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to the Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992, changing references from "Fund" to "Trust Fund" in various sections.
